com.ibm.xmi.framework
Interface ReaderAdapter

All Known Implementing Classes:
ReaderAdapterImpl, DefaultReaderAdapter
public interface ReaderAdapter

You can implement this interface to allow the framework to load XMI files and make instances of your classes or your own data without those classes implementing framework interfaces or inheriting from framework classes.

This interface implements an adapter design pattern. The framework invokes the methods in this interface to create objects and set the values of objects, and to get handlers to process XMI extensions. You can implement this interface to create instances of your own classes or to do other things with the data, like put it into a database, for instance.

The framework invokes the methods in this interface whether you load using the XMIFiles class or the XMIFile class.

The framework passes ValueInfo and ObjectInfo objects in some of the methods in this interface. You should not assume that you get a new ValueInfo object for each value or a new ObjectInfo object for each object; the framework might reuse ValueInfo and ObjectInfo objects.

Method Detail

createExtension

public org.xml.sax.ContentHandler createExtension(java.lang.Object object,
                                                  java.lang.String extender,
                                                  java.lang.String extenderID)
Make a document handler to handle the extension. If you want to ignore extensions, return null.
Parameters:
object - The object that owns the extension
extender - The value of the XML xmi.extender attribute
extenderID - The value of the XML xmi.extenderID attribute
Returns:
org.xml.sax.ContentHandler The SAX2 document handler for the extension, or null.

createObject

public java.lang.Object createObject(ObjectInfo info)
Make an object and return it. If you want the framework to resolve idrefs for you, you can return null when the idref parameter is set.

For example, for this XMI: 

 
 <o1>
   <o1.p1><o2 xmi.idref="_2"/></o1.p1>
 </o1>
 <o2 xmi.id="_2"/>

the framework will call the following methods:

  1. java.lang.Object o1 = createObject(info); // info xmiName: o1
  2. java.lang.Object ref = createObject(info); // info xmiName: o2, idref: _2
  3. java.lang.Object p1 = createProperty(fInfo); // fInfo object: o1 xmiName: p1 value: ref
  4. java.lang.Object o2 = createObject(info); // info xmiName: o2 id: _2
  5. setValue(o1, p1, o2);

NOTES:

  • The framework does not store the returned objects and properties in variables called o1, ref, p1, and o2--they are only for illustration to see how the values previously returned are used in later calls.
  • Call 5) above is not made unless call 2) returns null. If you want to resolve idrefs yourself, don't return null when createObject is called with a non-null idref. Call 3) is always called, even if ref is null.
  • setValue is never called for properties with string values.

For this XMI: 

 
 <o2 xmi.id="_2"/>
 <o1>
   <o1.p1><o2 xmi.idref="_2"/></o1.p1>
 </o1>

the framework will call the following methods:

  1. java.lang.Object o2 = createObject(info); // info xmiName: o2 id: _2
  2. java.lang.Object o1 = createObject(info); // info xmiName: o1
  3. java.lang.Object ref = createObject(info); // info xmiName: o2 idref: _2 
  4. If (ref != null)
             java.lang.Object p1 = createProperty(fInfo); // fInfo object: o1 xmiName: p1 value: ref
       else if (ref == null)
             java.lang.Object p1 = createProperty(fInfo); //fInfo object: o1 xmiName: p1 value: o2
Parameters:
info - The information about the new object
Returns:
The new object

setValue

public java.lang.Object setValue(ValueInfo info)
Set the value of the object given the information in the ValueInfo object; return an Object representing the value. This object is passed as the second argument to the other setValue method if the value to be set is an object that is later in the file.

setValue

public void setValue(java.lang.Object object,
                     java.lang.Object value,
                     java.lang.Object valueOfValue)
Set the value for the given object to the given value after forward references within the XMI file.
Parameters:
object - The object that owns the property.
value - An object representing the value.
valueOfValue - The value to set

endFile

public void endFile()
This method is invoked when the end of the XMI file is encountered. This method enables you to perform end of file processing, if necessary.

getType

public int getType(ValueInfo info)
Returns the type of the value given the information about the value in ValueInfo. If the type cannot be determined, return Value.DATA.
Parameters:
info - The information about the value
Returns:
The type

setXMIFile

public void setXMIFile(XMIFile file)
Provides access to the XMI file while the file is being created. This method is useful if you want (or need) access to header information for the file to help you process the file. It can be ignored if you do not need this information. It is called after the header data for the file has been processed.
Parameters:
file - The XMIFile object that will be returned from the load method

getType

public int getType(ObjectInfo info)
Returns WriterAdapter.OBJECT if the given xmiName is the xmiName of an object; otherwise, it returns -1. This method is called when an extension is encountered to determine whether to create an object or an XML element.
Parameters:
info - The object information for the potential object in an XMI extension
Returns:
WriterAdapter.OBJECT or -1
